content.description: Step out from the ledge and climb up right to the first bolt. Above, climb the grey slab with perfect grey limestone, using balance and footwork in typical slab fashion. Mostly easy with some thoughtfulness as it trends right in the middle of the climb.
content.location: Look for a ledge with a juniper below a nice-looking grey face. Two routes (as of Dec. 2011) climb from the right side of the ledge. This is the right hand of the two, with shiny stainless steel bolts. It's about 20 yards left of the two rightmost routes. You will need to scramble up to the ledge from the trail below and it seems easiest to do so from the far right of the climbs.

content.description: This is not really that fun.
content.location: It is the farthest left bolted route on the wall.

content.description:
Climb right from the ledge, clipping the first bolt on the

Unknown Grey Slab

. Move up and left, clipping the next bolt where the angle steepens. You may want to back clean the first bolt after getting the second clipped. Above, climb on beautiful grey limestone. Make use of the crack feature on the right. Move left at about the 4th bolt to gain the face above. The angle lessens, but the climbing is more difficult and thoughtful as you make slabby limestone moves that aren't always obvious. Finding a hidden jug before the finish helps ease the mind before you make the final moves to the anchor.
content.protection:
8 bolts and anchor. The 1st bolt is shared with the

Unknown Grey Slab

route to the right.
content.location: As of Dec. 2011, this is the left most bolted route on the grey slabs at the Homestead. Look for a ledge with a juniper below a nice looking grey wall. It's about 20 yards to the left of the two side by side routes on the right side of the area, including the route with the prominent red streak.

content.description: This is the farthest right bolted route on the wall.  The crux is right before the last bolt.  It is kind of an awkward traverse.
content.location: This is the farthest right bolted route on the wall.
